options.name: services.gnunet.load.maxNetDownBandwidth
options.desc: Maximum bandwidth usage (in bits per second) for GNUnet whendownloading data.

options.name: services.gnunet.load.hardNetUpBandwidth

options.name: services.gnunet.fileSharing.quota

options.name: services.awstats.configs.<name>.logFile

options.name: services.awstats.configs.<name>.hostAliases
options.desc: List of aliases the site has.

options.name: services.awstats.configs.<name>.domain

options.name: services.awstats.configs

name: Matomo
desc: A real-time web analytics application

options.name: services.matomo.package
options.desc: The matomo package to use.

options.name: services.matomo.enable
options.desc: Enable Matomo web analytics with php-fpm backend. Either the nginxoption or the webServerUser option is mandatory.

options.name: services.matomo.hostname
options.desc: URL of the host, without https prefix. You may want to change it ifyou run Matomo on a different URL than matomo.yourdomain.

options.name: services.matomo.periodicArchiveProcessing
options.desc: Enable periodic archive processing, which generates aggregatedreports from the visits.This means that you can safely disable browser triggers for Matomoarchiving, and safely enable to delete old visitor logs. Before deletingvisitor logs, make sure though that you runsystemctl start matomo-archive-processing.service at leastonce without errors if you have already collected data before.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx
options.desc: With this option, you can customize an nginx virtualHost whichalready has sensible defaults for Matomo. Either this option or thewebServerUser option is mandatory. Set this to {} to just enable thevirtualHost if you don’t need any customization. If enabled, then bydefault, the serverName is${user}.${config.networking.hostName}.${config.networking.domain},SSL is active, and certificates are acquired via ACME. If this is set tonull (the default), no nginx virtualHost will be configured.

options.name: services.matomo.webServerUser
options.desc: Name of the web server user that forwards requests to services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.socket thefastcgi socket for Matomo if the nginx option is not used. Either thisoption or the nginx option is mandatory. If you want to use anotherwebserver than nginx, you need to set this to that server’s user andpass fastcgi requests to index.php, matomo.phpand piwik.php (legacy name) to this socket.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.useACMEHost
options.desc: A host of an existing Let’s Encrypt certificate to use. This isuseful if you have many subdomains and want to avoid hitting the rate limit.Alternately, you can generate a certificate through enableACME. Note thatthis option does not create any certificates, nor it does add subdomainsto existing ones – you will need to create them manually using security.acme.certs.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.sslTrustedCertificate
options.desc: Path to root SSL certificate for stapling and clientcertificates.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.sslCertificateKey
options.desc: Path to server SSL certificate key.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.sslCertificate
options.desc: Path to server SSL certificate.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.serverName
options.desc: Name of this virtual host. Defaults to attribute name invirtualHosts.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.serverAliases
options.desc: Additional names of virtual hosts served by this virtual hostconfiguration.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.root
options.desc: The path of the web root directory.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.reuseport
options.desc: Create an individual listening socket . It is required to specifyonly once on one of the hosts.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.rejectSSL
options.desc: Whether to listen for and reject all HTTPS connections to this vhost.Useful in defaultserver blocks to avoid serving the certificate for another vhost. Usesthe ssl_reject_handshake directive available in nginxversions 1.19.4 and above.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.redirectCode
options.desc: HTTP status used by globalRedirect andforceSSL. Possible usecases include temporary (302, 307)redirects, keeping the request method and body (307, 308), or explicitlyresetting the method to GET (303). See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Redirections.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.quic
options.desc: Whether to enable the QUIC transport protocol. This requires usingpkgs.nginxQuic package which can be achieved by settingservices.nginx.package = pkgs.nginxQuic;. Note that QUICsupport is experimental and not yet recommended for production.Read more at https://quic.nginx.org/

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.onlySSL
options.desc: Whether to enable HTTPS and reject plain HTTP connections. This willset defaults for listen to listen on all interfaces on port443.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations.<name>.tryFiles
options.desc: Adds try_files directive.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations.<name>.root
options.desc: Root directory for requests.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations.<name>.return
options.desc: Adds a return directive, for e.g. redirections.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations.<name>.recommendedProxySettings
options.desc: Enable recommended proxy settings.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations.<name>.proxyWebsockets
options.desc: Whether to support proxying websocket connections with HTTP/1.1.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations.<name>.proxyPass
options.desc: Adds proxy_pass directive and sets recommended proxy headers ifrecommendedProxySettings is enabled.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations.<name>.priority
options.desc: Order of this location block in relation to the others in the vhost.The semantics are the same as with lib.mkOrder. Smallervalues have a greater priority.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations.<name>.index
options.desc: Adds index directive.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations.<name>.fastcgiParams
options.desc: FastCGI parameters to override. Unlike in the Nginx configurationfile, overriding only some default parameters won’t unset the defaultvalues for other parameters.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations.<name>.extraConfig
options.desc: These lines go to the end of the location verbatim.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations.<name>.basicAuthFile
options.desc: Basic Auth password file for a vhost. Can be created via: htpasswd -c <filename> <username>.WARNING: The generate file contains the users’ passwords in anon-cryptographically-securely hashed way.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations.<name>.basicAuth
options.desc: Basic Auth protection for a vhost.WARNING: This is implemented to store the password in plain text inthe Nix store.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations.<name>.alias
options.desc: Alias directory for requests.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.locations
options.desc: Declarative location config

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.listenAddresses
options.desc: Listen addresses for this virtual host. Compared tolisten this only sets the addresses and the ports arechosen automatically.Note: This option overrides enableIPv6

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.listen.*.ssl
options.desc: Enable SSL.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.listen.*.proxyProtocol
options.desc: Enable PROXY protocol.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.listen.*.port
options.desc: Port number to listen on. If unset and the listen address is not asocket then nginx defaults to 80.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.listen.*.extraParameters
options.desc: Extra parameters of this listen directive.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.listen.*.addr
options.desc: Listen address.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.listen
options.desc: Listen addresses and ports for this virtual host. IPv6 addresses mustbe enclosed in square brackets. Note: this option overridesaddSSL and onlySSL.If you only want to set the addresses manually and not the ports,take a look at listenAddresses.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.kTLS
options.desc: Whether to enable kTLS support. Implementing TLS in the kernel (kTLS)improves performance by significantly reducing the need for copyingoperations between user space and the kernel. Required Nginx version1.21.4 or later.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.http3_hq
options.desc: Whether to enable the HTTP/0.9 protocol negotiation used in QUICinteroperability tests. This requires using pkgs.nginxQuicpackage which can be achieved by settingservices.nginx.package = pkgs.nginxQuic; and activate theQUIC transport protocolservices.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.quic = true;. Notethat special application protocol support is experimental andnot yet recommended for production. Read more at https://quic.nginx.org/

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.http3
options.desc: Whether to enable the HTTP/3 protocol. This requires usingpkgs.nginxQuic package which can be achieved by settingservices.nginx.package = pkgs.nginxQuic; and activate theQUIC transport protocolservices.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.quic = true;. Notethat HTTP/3 support is experimental and not yet recommended forproduction. Read more at https://quic.nginx.org/ HTTP/3availability must be manually advertised, preferably in each locationblock.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.http2
options.desc: Whether to enable the HTTP/2 protocol. Note that (as of writing) dueto nginx’s implementation, to disable HTTP/2 you have to disable it onall vhosts that use a given IP address / port. If there is one serverblock configured to enable http2, then it is enabled for all serverblocks on this IP. See https://stackoverflow.com/a/39466948/263061.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.globalRedirect
options.desc: If set, all requests for this host are redirected (defaults to 301,configurable with redirectCode) to the given hostname.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.forceSSL
options.desc: Whether to add a separate nginx server block that redirects (defaultsto 301, configurable with redirectCode) all plain HTTPtraffic to HTTPS. This will set defaults for listen tolisten on all interfaces on the respective default ports (80, 443),where the non-SSL listens are used for the redirect vhosts.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.extraConfig
options.desc: These lines go to the end of the vhost verbatim.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.enableACME
options.desc: Whether to ask Let’s Encrypt to sign a certificate for this vhost.Alternately, you can use an existing certificate through useACMEHost.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.default
options.desc: Makes this vhost the default.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.basicAuthFile
options.desc: Basic Auth password file for a vhost. Can be created via: htpasswd -c <filename> <username>.WARNING: The generate file contains the users’ passwords in anon-cryptographically-securely hashed way.

options.name: services.matomo.nginx.basicAuth
options.desc: Basic Auth protection for a vhost.WARNING: This is implemented to store the password in plain text inthe Nix store.

name: Ollama
desc: Get up and running with large language models locally

options.name: services.ollama.environmentVariables
options.desc: Set arbitrary environment variables for the ollama service.Be aware that these are only seen by the ollama server (systemdservice), not normal invocations like ollama run. Sinceollama run is mostly a shell around the ollama server, thisis usually sufficient.

options.name: services.ollama.package
options.desc: The ollama package to use.

options.name: services.ollama.listenAddress
options.desc: The address which the ollama server HTTP interface binds and listensto.

options.name: services.ollama.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable ollama server for local large language models.

options.name: services.ollama.home
options.desc: The home directory that the ollama service is started in.See also services.ollama.writablePaths andservices.ollama.sandbox.

options.name: services.ollama.models
options.desc: The directory that the ollama service will read models from anddownload new models to.See also services.ollama.writablePaths andservices.ollama.sandbox if downloading models or othermutation of the filesystem is required.

options.name: services.ollama.writablePaths
options.desc: Paths that the server should have write access to.This sets ReadWritePaths,which allows specified paths to be written to through the defaultsandboxing.See also services.ollama.sandbox.

options.name: services.ollama.sandbox
options.desc: Whether to enable systemd’s sandboxing capabilities.This sets DynamicUser,which runs the server as a unique user with read-only access to most ofthe filesystem.See also services.ollama.writablePaths.

options.name: services.ollama.acceleration
options.desc: What interface to use for hardware acceleration.null: default behavior ifnixpkgs.config.rocmSupport is enabled, uses"rocm" if nixpkgs.config.cudaSupport isenabled, uses "cuda" otherwise defaults tofalsefalse: disable GPU, only use CPU"rocm": supported by most modern AMD GPUs"cuda": supported by most modern NVIDIA GPUs

options.desc: Whether to enable changedetection-io.

options.name: services.changedetection-io.datastorePath

options.name: services.changedetection-io.environmentFile

SALTED_PASS should be 64characters long while the first 32 are the salt and the second thefrontend password. It can easily be retrieved from the settings filewhen first set via the frontend with the following command:jq -r .settings.application.password /var/lib/changedetection-io/url-watches.json

options.name: services.changedetection-io.baseURL

options.desc: Whether the user has accepted to submit anonymous usage data. Thedefault, 0, mean the user has not made a choice, and Syncthing will askat some point in the future. “-1” means no, a number above zero meansthat that version of usage reporting has been accepted.

options.name: services.syncthing.settings.folders.<name>.copyOwnershipFromParent
options.desc: On Unix systems, tries to copy file/folder ownership from the parentdirectory (the directory it’s located in). Requires running Syncthing asa privileged user, or granting it additional capabilities (e.g.CAP_CHOWN on Linux).

options.name: services.syncthing.settings.folders

options.name: services.syncthing.settings.folders.<name>.versioning

options.name: services.syncthing.settings.devices
options.desc: Peers/devices which Syncthing should communicate with.Note that you can still add devices manually, but those changes willbe reverted on restart if overrideDevicesis enabled.

options.name: services.syncthing.openDefaultPorts
options.desc: Whether to open the default ports in the firewall: TCP/UDP 22000 fortransfers and UDP 21027 for discovery.If multiple users are running Syncthing on this machine, you willneed to manually open a set of ports for each instance and leave thisdisabled. Alternatively, if you are running only a single instance onthis machine using the default ports, enable this.

options.name: services.syncthing.settings
options.desc: Extra configuration options for Syncthing. See https://docs.syncthing.net/users/config.html.Note that this attribute set does not exactly match the documented xmlformat. Instead, this is the format of the json rest api. There areslight differences. For example, this xml:<options>  <listenAddress>default</listenAddress>  <minHomeDiskFree unit="%">1</minHomeDiskFree></options>corresponds to the json:{  options: {    listenAddresses = [      "default"    ];    minHomeDiskFree = {      unit = "%";      value = 1;    };  };}

options.name: services.syncthing.settings.options.relaysEnabled

options.name: services.syncthing.settings.options.maxFolderConcurrency

You cangenerate one by runningopenssl rand -hex 64 >/path/to/secret_key_base_fileThis should be a string, not a nix path, since nix paths are copiedinto the world-readable nix store.

options.name: services.discourse.database.ignorePostgresqlVersion
options.desc: Whether to allow other versions of PostgreSQL than the recommendedone. Only effective when services.discourse.database.createLocally isenabled.

options.name: services.discourse.database.createLocally
options.desc: Whether a database should be automatically created on the local host.Set this to false if you plan on provisioning a localdatabase yourself. This has no effect if services.discourse.database.host is customized.

options.name: services.discourse.admin.username
options.desc: The admin user username.

options.name: services.discourse.admin.skipCreate
options.desc: Do not create the admin account, instead rely on other existing adminaccounts.

options.name: services.discourse.admin.passwordFile
options.desc: A path to a file containing the admin user’s password.This should be a string, not a nix path, since nix paths are copiedinto the world-readable nix store.

options.name: services.discourse.admin.fullName
options.desc: The admin user’s full name.

options.name: services.discourse.admin.email
options.desc: The admin user email address.

name: Mastodon
desc: Self-hosted, globally interconnected microblogging software based on ActivityPub

options.name: services.mastodon.package
options.desc: Mastodon package to use.

options.name: services.mastodon.user
options.desc: User under which mastodon runs. If it is set to “mastodon”, that userwill be created, otherwise it should be set to the name of a usercreated elsewhere. In both cases, the mastodon package willbe added to the user’s package set and a tootctl wrapper to systempackages that switches to the configured account and load the rightenvironment.

options.name: services.mastodon.webProcesses
options.desc: Processes used by the mastodon-web service.

options.name: services.mastodon.redis.createLocally
options.desc: Configure local Redis server for Mastodon.

options.name: services.mastodon.localDomain
options.desc: The domain serving your Mastodon instance.

options.name: services.mastodon.group
options.desc: Group under which mastodon runs.

options.name: services.mastodon.webPort
options.desc: TCP port used by the mastodon-web service.

options.name: services.mastodon.smtp.createLocally
options.desc: Configure local Postfix SMTP server for Mastodon.

options.name: services.mastodon.sidekiqPort
options.desc: TCP port used by the mastodon-sidekiq service.

options.name: services.mastodon.database.createLocally
options.desc: Configure local PostgreSQL database server for Mastodon.

options.name: services.mastodon.webThreads
options.desc: Threads per process used by the mastodon-web service.

options.name: services.mastodon.extraConfig
options.desc: Extra environment variables to pass to all mastodon services.

options.name: services.mastodon.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable Mastodon, a federated social network server.

options.name: services.mastodon.configureNginx
options.desc: Configure nginx as a reverse proxy for mastodon. Note that this makessome assumptions on your setup, and sets settings that will affect othervirtualHosts running on your nginx instance, if any. Alternatively youcan configure a reverse-proxy of your choice to serve these paths:/ -> $(nix-instantiate --eval '<nixpkgs>' -A mastodon.outPath)/public/ -> 127.0.0.1:{{ webPort }} (If there was no file inthe directory above.)/system/ -> /var/lib/mastodon/public-system//api/v1/streaming/ -> 127.0.0.1:{{ streamingPort }}Make sure that websockets are forwarded properly. You might want toset up caching of some requests. Take a look at mastodon’s providednginx configuration athttps://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/blob/master/dist/nginx.conf.

options.name: services.mastodon.trustedProxy
options.desc: You need to set it to the IP from which your reverse proxy sendsrequests to Mastodon’s web process, otherwise Mastodon will record thereverse proxy’s own IP as the IP of all requests, which would be badbecause IP addresses are used for important rate limits and securityfunctions.

options.name: services.mastodon.extraEnvFiles
options.desc: Extra environment files to pass to all mastodon services. Useful forpassing down environmental secrets.

options.name: services.mastodon.streamingProcesses
options.desc: Number of processes used by the mastodon-streaming service. Pleasedefine this explicitly, recommended is the amount of your CPU coresminus one.

options.name: services.mastodon.sidekiqThreads
options.desc: Worker threads used by the mastodon-sidekiq-all service. IfsidekiqProcesses is configured and any processes specifynull threads, this value is used.

options.name: services.mastodon.otpSecretFile
options.desc: Path to file containing the OTP secret. A new OTP secret can begenerated by running:nix build -f '<nixpkgs>' mastodon; cd result; bin/rake secretIf this file does not exist, it will be created with a new OTPsecret.

options.name: services.mastodon.secretKeyBaseFile
options.desc: Path to file containing the secret key base. A new secret key basecan be generated by running:nix build -f '<nixpkgs>' mastodon; cd result; bin/rake secretIf this file does not exist, it will be created with a new secret keybase.

options.name: services.mastodon.vapidPrivateKeyFile
options.desc: Path to file containing the private key used for Web Push VoluntaryApplication Server Identification. A new keypair can be generated byrunning:nix build -f '<nixpkgs>' mastodon; cd result; bin/rake webpush:generate_keysIf this file does not exist, it will be created with a new privatekey.

options.name: services.mastodon.vapidPublicKeyFile
options.desc: Path to file containing the public key used for Web Push VoluntaryApplication Server Identification. A new keypair can be generated byrunning:nix build -f '<nixpkgs>' mastodon; cd result; bin/rake webpush:generate_keysIf mastodon.vapidPrivateKeyFiledoes not exist, it andthis file will be created with a new keypair.

options.name: services.mastodon.smtp.user
options.desc: SMTP login name.

options.name: services.mastodon.smtp.port
options.desc: SMTP port used when sending emails to users.

options.name: services.mastodon.smtp.passwordFile
options.desc: Path to file containing the SMTP password.

options.name: services.mastodon.smtp.host
options.desc: SMTP host used when sending emails to users.

options.name: services.mastodon.smtp.fromAddress
options.desc: “From” address used when sending Emails to users.

options.name: services.mastodon.smtp.authenticate
options.desc: Authenticate with the SMTP server using username and password.

options.name: services.mastodon.sidekiqProcesses.<name>.threads
options.desc: Number of threads this process should use for executing jobs. Ifnull, the configured sidekiqThreads are used.

options.name: services.mastodon.sidekiqProcesses.<name>.jobClasses
options.desc: If not empty, which job classes should be executed by this process.Only one process should handle the ‘scheduler’ class. If left empty,this process will handle the ‘scheduler’ class.

options.name: services.mastodon.sidekiqProcesses
options.desc: How many Sidekiq processes should be used to handle background jobs,and which job classes they handle. Read the upstreamdocumentation before configuring this!

options.name: services.mastodon.redis.port
options.desc: Redis port.

options.name: services.mastodon.redis.passwordFile
options.desc: A file containing the password for Redis database.

options.name: services.mastodon.redis.host
options.desc: Redis host.

options.name: services.mastodon.redis.enableUnixSocket
options.desc: Use Unix socket

options.name: services.mastodon.mediaAutoRemove.startAt
options.desc: How often to remove remote media.The format is described in systemd.time(7).

options.name: services.mastodon.mediaAutoRemove.olderThanDays
options.desc: How old remote media needs to be in order to be removed.

options.name: services.mastodon.mediaAutoRemove.enable
options.desc: Automatically remove remote media attachments and preview cards olderthan the configured amount of days.Recommended in https://docs.joinmastodon.org/admin/setup/.

options.name: services.mastodon.enableUnixSocket
options.desc: Instead of binding to an IP address like 127.0.0.1, you may bind to aUnix socket. This variable is process-specific, e.g. you need differentvalues for every process, and it works for both web (Puma) processes andstreaming API (Node.js) processes.

options.name: services.mastodon.elasticsearch.user
options.desc: Used for optionally authenticating with Elasticsearch.

options.name: services.mastodon.elasticsearch.preset
options.desc: It controls the ElasticSearch indices configuration (number of shardsand replica).

options.name: services.mastodon.elasticsearch.port
options.desc: Elasticsearch port.

options.name: services.mastodon.elasticsearch.passwordFile
options.desc: Path to file containing password for optionally authenticating withElasticsearch.

options.name: services.mastodon.elasticsearch.host
options.desc: Elasticsearch host. If it is not null, Elasticsearch full text searchwill be enabled.

options.name: services.mastodon.database.user
options.desc: Database user.

options.name: services.mastodon.database.port
options.desc: Database host port.

options.name: services.mastodon.database.passwordFile
options.desc: A file containing the password corresponding to database.user.

options.name: services.mastodon.database.name
options.desc: Database name.

options.name: services.mastodon.database.host
options.desc: Database host address or unix socket.

options.name: services.mastodon.automaticMigrations
options.desc: Do automatic database migrations.

name: Jitsi Meet
desc: Secure, Simple and Scalable Video Conferences

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.caddy.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable Whether to enable caddy reverse proxy to exposejitsi-meet.

options.name: services.jibri.ignoreCert
options.desc: Whether to enable the flag “–ignore-certificate-errors” for theChromium browser opened by Jibri. Intended for use in automated tests oranywhere else where using a verified cert for Jitsi-Meet is notpossible.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.videobridge.passwordFile
options.desc: File containing password to the Prosody account for videobridge.If null, a file with password will be generatedautomatically. Setting this option is useful if you plan to connectadditional videobridges to the XMPP server.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.videobridge.enable
options.desc: Jitsi Videobridge instance and configure it to connect toProsody.Additional configuration is possible with services.jitsi-videobridge

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.secureDomain.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable Authenticated room creation.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.secureDomain.authentication
options.desc: The authentication type to be used by jitsi

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.prosody.enable
options.desc: Whether to configure Prosody to relay XMPP messages between JitsiMeet components. Turn this off if you want to configure it manually.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.nginx.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable nginx virtual host that will serve the javascriptapplication and act as a proxy for the XMPP server. Further nginxconfiguration can be done by adapting services.nginx.virtualHosts.<hostName>. Whenthis is enabled, ACME will be used to retrieve a TLS certificate bydefault. To disable this, set the services.nginx.virtualHosts.<hostName>.enableACMEto false and if appropriate do the same for services.nginx.virtualHosts.<hostName>.forceSSL.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.jigasi.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable jigasi instance and configure it to connect toProsody.Additional configuration is possible withservices.jigasi.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.jicofo.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable JiCoFo instance and configure it to connect toProsody.Additional configuration is possible with services.jicofo.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.jibri.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable a Jibri instance and configure it to connect toProsody.Additional configuration is possible with services.jibri, and services.jibri.finalizeScript is especiallyuseful.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.interfaceConfig
options.desc: Client-side web-app interface settings that override the defaults ininterface_config.js.See https://github.com/jitsi/jitsi-meet/blob/master/interface_config.jsfor default configuration with comments.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.hostName
options.desc: FQDN of the Jitsi Meet instance.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.extraConfig
options.desc: Text to append to config.js web application config file.Can be used to insert JavaScript logic to determine user’s region incascading bridges setup.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.excalidraw.port
options.desc: The port which the Excalidraw backend for Jitsi should listen to.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.excalidraw.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable Excalidraw collaboration backend for Jitsi.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable Jitsi Meet - Secure, Simple and Scalable VideoConferences.

options.name: services.jitsi-meet.config
options.desc: Client-side web application settings that override the defaults inconfig.js.See https://github.com/jitsi/jitsi-meet/blob/master/config.jsfor default configuration with comments.

name: Barman
desc: Backup and Recovery Manager for PostgreSQL

name: BorgBackup
desc: Deduplicating archiver with compression and encryption

options.name: services.borgbackup.package
options.desc: The borgbackup package to use.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs
options.desc: Deduplicating backups using BorgBackup. Adding a job will cause aborg-job-NAME wrapper to be added to your system path, so that you canperform maintenance easily. See also the chapter about BorgBackup in theNixOS manual.

options.name: services.borgbackup.repos
options.desc: Serve BorgBackup repositories to given public SSH keys, restrictingtheir access to the repository only. See also the chapter aboutBorgBackup in the NixOS manual. Also, clients do not need to specify theabsolute path when accessing the repository, i.e.user@machine:. is enough. (Note colon and dot.)

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.startAt
options.desc: When or how often the backup should run. Must be in the formatdescribed in systemd.time(7). Ifyou do not want the backup to start automatically, use [ ].It will generate a systemd service borgbackup-job-NAME. You may triggerit manually via systemctl restart borgbackup-job-NAME.

options.name: services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.user
options.desc: The user borg serve is run as. User or group needs writepermission for the specified path.

options.name: services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.quota
options.desc: Storage quota for the repository. This quota is ensured for allsub-repositories if allowSubRepos is enabled but not for the overallstorage space used.

options.name: services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.path
options.desc: Where to store the backups. Note that the directory is createdautomatically, with correct permissions.

options.name: services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.group
options.desc: The group borg serve is run as. User or group needs writepermission for the specified path.

options.name: services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.authorizedKeysAppendOnly
options.desc: Public SSH keys that can only be used to append new data (archives)to the repository. Note that archives can still be marked as deleted andare subsequently removed from disk upon accessing the repo with fullwrite access, e.g. when pruning.

options.name: services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.authorizedKeys
options.desc: Public SSH keys that are given full write access to this repository.You should use a different SSH key for each repository you write to,because the specified keys are restricted to running borg serve and can onlyaccess this single repository.

options.name: services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.allowSubRepos
options.desc: Allow clients to create repositories in subdirectories of thespecified path.These can be accessed using user@machine:path/to/subrepo.Note that a quotaapplies to repositories independently. Therefore, if this is enabled,clients can create multiple repositories and upload an arbitrary amountof data.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.user
options.desc: The user borg isrun as. User or group need read permission for the specified paths.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.repo
options.desc: Remote or local repository to back up to.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.removableDevice
options.desc: Whether the repo (which must be local) is a removable device.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.readWritePaths
options.desc: By default, borg cannot write anywhere on the system but$HOME/.config/borg and $HOME/.cache/borg. If,for example, your preHook script needs to dump files somewhere, putthose directories here.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.prune.prefix
options.desc: Only consider archive names starting with this prefix for pruning. Bydefault, only archives created by this job are considered. Use"" or null to consider all archives.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.prune.keep
options.desc: Prune a repository by deleting all archives not matching any of thespecified retention options. See borg help prune for the available options.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.privateTmp
options.desc: Set the PrivateTmp option for the systemd-service. Setto false if you need sockets or other files from global /tmp.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.preHook
options.desc: Shell commands to run before the backup. This can for example be usedto mount file systems.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.postPrune
options.desc: Shell commands to run after borg prune.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.postInit
options.desc: Shell commands to run after borg init.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.postHook
options.desc: Shell commands to run just before exit. They are executed even if aprevious command exits with a non-zero exit code. The latter isavailable as $exitStatus.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.postCreate
options.desc: Shell commands to run after borg create. The name of the created archive isstored in $archiveName.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.persistentTimer
options.desc: Set the Persistent option for the systemd.timer(5)which triggers the backup immediately if the last trigger was missed(e.g. if the system was powered down).

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.patterns
options.desc: Include/exclude paths matching the given patterns. The first matchingpatterns is used, so if an include pattern (prefix +)matches before an exclude pattern (prefix -), the file isbacked up. See borg help patternsfor pattern syntax.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.paths
options.desc: Path(s) to back up. Mutually exclusive with dumpCommand.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.inhibitsSleep
options.desc: Prevents the system from sleeping while backing up.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.group
options.desc: The group borg is run as. User or group needs read permission for thespecified paths.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.failOnWarnings
options.desc: Fail the whole backup job if any borg command returns a warning (exitcode 1), for example because a file changed during backup.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.extraPruneArgs
options.desc: Additional arguments for borg prune. Can also be set at runtime using$extraPruneArgs.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.extraInitArgs
options.desc: Additional arguments for borg init. Can also be set at runtime using$extraInitArgs.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.extraCreateArgs
options.desc: Additional arguments for borg create. Can also be set at runtime using$extraCreateArgs.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.extraCompactArgs
options.desc: Additional arguments for borg compact. Can also be set at runtime using$extraCompactArgs.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.extraArgs
options.desc: Additional arguments for all borg calls the service has. Handle with care.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.exclude
options.desc: Exclude paths matching any of the given patterns. See borg help patterns forpattern syntax.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.environment
options.desc: Environment variables passed to the backup script. You can forexample specify which SSH key to use.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.encryption.passphrase
options.desc: The passphrase the backups are encrypted with. Mutually exclusivewith passCommand. Ifyou do not want the passphrase to be stored in the world-readable Nixstore, use passCommand.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.encryption.passCommand
options.desc: A command which prints the passphrase to stdout. Mutually exclusivewith passphrase.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.encryption.mode
options.desc: Encryption mode to use. Setting a mode other than "none"requires you to specify a passCommand or a passphrase.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.dumpCommand
options.desc: Backup the stdout of this program instead of filesystem paths.Mutually exclusive with paths.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.doInit
options.desc: Run borg init ifthe specified repodoes not exist. You should set this to false if therepository is located on an external drive that might not always bemounted.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.dateFormat
options.desc: Arguments passed to date to create a timestamp suffix for the archivename.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.compression
options.desc: Compression method to use. Refer to borg help compression for all availableoptions.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.archiveBaseName
options.desc: How to name the created archives. A timestamp, whose format isdetermined by dateFormat, will be appended. The full name can bemodified at runtime ($archiveName). Placeholders like{hostname} must not be used. Use null for nobase name.

options.name: services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.appendFailedSuffix
options.desc: Append a .failed suffix to the archive name, which isonly removed if borg create has a zero exit status.

options.name: services.tabby.acceleration
options.desc: Specifies the device to use for hardware acceleration.cpu: no acceleration just use the CPUrocm: supported by modern AMD GPUscuda: supported by modern NVIDIA GPUsmetal: supported on darwin aarch64 machinesTabby will try and determine what type of acceleration that isalready enabled in your configuration whenacceleration = null.nixpkgs.config.cudaSupportnixpkgs.config.rocmSupportif stdenv.isDarwin && stdenv.isAarch64IFF multiple acceleration methods are found to be enabled or if youhaven’t set either cudaSupport or rocmSupport you will haveto specify the device type manually here otherwise it will default tothe first from the list above or to cpu.

options.name: services.prometheus.exporters.exportarr-radarr.listenAddress
options.desc: Address to listen on.

options.name: services.prometheus.exporters.exportarr-radarr.group
options.desc: Group under which the exportarr-radarr exporter shall be run.

options.name: services.prometheus.exporters.exportarr-radarr.firewallRules
options.desc: Specify rules for nftables to add to the input chain when services.prometheus.exporters.exportarr-radarr.openFirewallis true.

options.name: services.prometheus.exporters.exportarr-radarr.firewallFilter
options.desc: Specify a filter for iptables to use when services.prometheus.exporters.exportarr-radarr.openFirewallis true. It is used asip46tables -I nixos-fw firewallFilter -j nixos-fw-accept.

options.name: services.prometheus.exporters.exportarr-radarr.extraFlags
options.desc: Extra commandline options to pass to the exportarr-radarrexporter.

options.name: services.prometheus.exporters.exportarr-radarr.environment

options.desc: Whether to enable the prometheus exportarr-radarr exporter.

options.name: services.prometheus.exporters.exportarr-lidarr.url

options.desc: Port to listen on.

options.name: services.prometheus.exporters.exportarr-lidarr.openFirewall
options.desc: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

options.name: services.prometheus.exporters.exportarr-lidarr.listenAddress

Disabling willdelete this file again.See also: https://gluster.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Administrator%20Guide/SSL/

options.name: services.glusterfs.killMode
options.desc: The systemd KillMode to use for glusterd.glusterd spawns other daemons like gsyncd. If you want these to stopwhen glusterd is stopped (e.g. to ensure that NixOS config changes arereflected even for these sub-daemons), set this to ‘control-group’. Ifhowever you want running volume processes (glusterfsd) and thus glustermounts not be interrupted when glusterd is restarted (for example, whenyou want to restart them manually at a later time), set this to‘process’.

Todisable a wildcard plugin, use an actual wildcard, as in theexample.munin_stats is disabled by default as it tries to read/var/log/munin/munin-update.log for timing information, andthe NixOS build of Munin does not write this file.

options.name: services.munin-cron.extraCSS
options.desc: Custom styling for the HTML that munin-cron generates. This will beappended to the CSS files used by munin-cron and will thus takeprecedence over the builtin styles.

options.name: services.munin-node.enable
options.desc: Enable Munin Node agent. Munin node listens on 0.0.0.0 and by defaultaccepts connections only from 127.0.0.1 for security reasons.See https://guide.munin-monitoring.org/en/latest/architecture/index.html.

options.name: services.munin-node.extraAutoPlugins
options.desc: Additional Munin plugins to autoconfigure, usingmunin-node-configure --suggest. These should be the actualpaths to the plugin files (or directories containing them), not justtheir names.If you want to manually enable individual plugins instead, use services.munin-node.extraPlugins.Note that only plugins that have the ‘autoconfig’ capability will doanything if listed here, since plugins that cannot autoconfigure won’tbe automatically enabled by munin-node-configure.Plugins will be copied into the Nix store, and it will attempt tomodify them to run properly by fixing hardcoded references to/bin, /usr/bin, /sbin, and/usr/sbin.

options.name: services.munin-node.extraPlugins
options.desc: Additional Munin plugins to activate. Keys are the name of the pluginsymlink, values are the path to the underlying plugin script. You canuse the same plugin script multiple times (e.g. for wildcardplugins).Note that these plugins do not participate in autoconfiguration. Ifyou want to autoconfigure additional plugins, use services.munin-node.extraAutoPlugins.Plugins enabled in this manner take precedence over autoconfiguredplugins.Plugins will be copied into the Nix store, and it will attempt tomodify them to run properly by fixing hardcoded references to/bin, /usr/bin, /sbin, and/usr/sbin.

options.name: services.munin-cron.extraGlobalConfig

options.desc: List of paths to Privoxy filter files. These paths may either beabsolute or relative to the privoxy configuration directory.

options.desc: This option is mapped to the main Privoxy configuration file. Checkout the Privoxy user manual at https://www.privoxy.org/user-manual/config.htmlfor available settings and documentation.Repeated settings can be represented by using a list.

options.name: services.privoxy.inspectHttps
options.desc: Whether to configure Privoxy to inspect HTTPS requests, meaning allencrypted traffic will be filtered as well. This works by decrypting andre-encrypting the requests using a per-domain generated certificate.To issue per-domain certificates, Privoxy must be provided with a CAcertificate, using the ca-cert-file,ca-key-file settings.The CA certificate must also be added to the system trust roots,otherwise browsers will reject all Privoxy certificates as invalid. Youcan do so by using the option security.pki.certificateFiles.

options.name: services.privoxy.certsLifetime
options.desc: If inspectHttps is enabled, the time generated HTTPScertificates will be stored in a temporary directory for reuse. Once thelifetime has expired the directory will cleared and the certificate willhave to be generated again, on-demand.Depending on the traffic, you may want to reduce the lifetime tolimit the disk usage, since Privoxy itself never deletes thecertificates.The format is that of the tmpfiles.d(5) Ageparameter.

options.name: services.privoxy.userFilters
options.desc: Filters to be included in a user.filter file. This willhave a higher priority and can be used to override all other filtersdefinitions.

options.name: services.privoxy.userActions
options.desc: Actions to be included in a user.action file. This willhave a higher priority and can be used to override all otheractions.

options.desc: Pair of address:port the proxy server is listening to.

options.name: services.gitolite.extraGitoliteRc
options.desc: Extra configuration to append to the default~/.gitolite.rc.This should be Perl code that modifies the %RCconfiguration variable. The default ~/.gitolite.rc contentis generated by invoking gitolite print-default-rc, andextra configuration from this option is appended to it. The result isplaced to Nix store, and the ~/.gitolite.rc file becomes asymlink to it.If you already have a customized (or otherwise changed)~/.gitolite.rc file, NixOS will refuse to replace it with asymlink, and the gitolite-init initialization service willfail. In this situation, in order to use this option, you will need totake any customizations you may have in ~/.gitolite.rc,convert them to appropriate Perl statements, add them to this option,and remove the file.See also the enableGitAnnex option.

options.name: services.gitolite.enableGitAnnex

options.name: services.gitolite.commonHooks

options.desc: The strongswan package to use.

options.desc: Whether to enable strongswan-swanctl service.

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools.<name>.subnet
options.desc: Address or CIDR subnetsStrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools.<name>.split_include
options.desc: Address or CIDR subnetsStrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools.<name>.split_exclude
options.desc: Address or CIDR subnetsStrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools.<name>.server
options.desc: Address or CIDR subnetsStrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools.<name>.netmask
options.desc: Address or CIDR subnetsStrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools.<name>.nbns
options.desc: Address or CIDR subnetsStrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools.<name>.dns
options.desc: Address or CIDR subnetsStrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools.<name>.dhcp
options.desc: Address or CIDR subnetsStrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.authorities.<name>.ocsp_uris
options.desc: List of OCSP URIs.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.ppk_required
options.desc: Whether a Postquantum Preshared Key (PPK) is required for thisconnection.StrongSwan default: false

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.children.<name>.hostaccess
options.desc: Hostaccess variable to pass to updown script.StrongSwan default: false

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.authorities.<name>.crl_uris
options.desc: List of CRL distribution points (ldap, http, or file URI).StrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.remote.<name>.cert_policy
options.desc: List of certificate policy OIDs the peer’s certificate must have.OIDs are specified using the numerical dotted representation.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan.managePlugins
options.desc: If set to true, this option will disable automatic plugin loading andthen tell strongSwan to enable the plugins specified in the enabledPlugins option.

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.remote.<name>.round
options.desc: Optional numeric identifier by which authentication rounds aresorted. If not specified rounds are ordered by their position in theconfig file/vici message.StrongSwan default: 0

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.local.<name>.round
options.desc: Optional numeric identifier by which authentication rounds aresorted. If not specified rounds are ordered by their position in theconfig file/vici message.StrongSwan default: 0

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.remote.<name>.certs
options.desc: List of certificates to accept for authentication. The certificatesmay use a relative path from the swanctl x509 directory oran absolute path.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.remote.<name>.id
options.desc: IKE identity to expect for authentication round. When usingcertificate authentication, the IKE identity must be contained in thecertificate, either as subject or as subjectAltName.StrongSwan default: "%any"

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.remote.<name>.cacerts
options.desc: List of CA certificates to accept for authentication. Thecertificates may use a relative path from the swanctlx509ca directory or an absolute path.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.children.<name>.remote_ts
options.desc: List of remote selectors to include in CHILD_SA. See local_ts for a descriptionof the selector syntax.StrongSwan default: ["dynamic"]

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.children.<name>.ipcomp
options.desc: Enable IPComp compression before encryption. If enabled, IKE tries tonegotiate IPComp compression to compress ESP payload data prior toencryption.StrongSwan default: false

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.mediation
options.desc: Whether this connection is a mediation connection, that is, whetherthis connection is used to mediate other connections using the IKEv2Mediation Extension. Mediation connections create no CHILD_SA.StrongSwan default: false

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.children.<name>.policies
options.desc: Whether to install IPsec policies or not. Disabling this can beuseful in some scenarios e.g. MIPv6, where policies are not managed bythe IKE daemon. Since 5.3.3.StrongSwan default: true

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.remote.<name>.pubkeys
options.desc: List of raw public keys to accept for authentication. The public keysmay use a relative path from the swanctl pubkey directoryor an absolute path.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.children.<name>.policies_fwd_out
options.desc: Whether to install outbound FWD IPsec policies or not. Enabling thisis required in case there is a drop policy that would match and blockforwarded traffic for this CHILD_SA. Since 5.5.1.StrongSwan default: false

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.reauth_time
options.desc: Time to schedule IKE reauthentication. IKE reauthentication recreatesthe IKE/ISAKMP SA from scratch and re-evaluates the credentials. Inasymmetric configurations (with EAP or configuration payloads) it mightnot be possible to actively reauthenticate as responder. The IKEv2reauthentication lifetime negotiation can instruct the client to performreauthentication.Reauthentication is disabled by default. Enabling it usually may leadto small connection interruptions, as strongSwan uses abreak-before-make policy with IKEv2 to avoid any conflicts withassociated tunnel resources.StrongSwan default: "0s"

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.children.<name>.copy_ecn
options.desc: Whether to copy the ECN (Explicit Congestion Notification) headerfield to/from the outer IP header in tunnel mode. Controlling thisbehavior is not supported by all kernel interfaces.StrongSwan default: true

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.dscp
options.desc: Differentiated Services Field Codepoint to set on outgoing IKEpackets for this connection. The value is a six digit binary encodedstring specifying the Codepoint to set, as defined in RFC 2474.StrongSwan default: "000000"

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.children.<name>.copy_df
options.desc: Whether to copy the DF bit to the outer IPv4 header in tunnel mode.This effectively disables Path MTU discovery (PMTUD). Controlling thisbehavior is not supported by all kernel interfaces.StrongSwan default: true

options.name: networking.networkmanager.enableStrongSwan
options.desc: Enable the StrongSwan plugin.If you enable this option the networkmanager_strongswanplugin will be added to the networking.networkmanager.plugins option so youdon’t need to do that yourself.

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.pools
options.desc: List of named IP pools to allocate virtual IP addresses and otherconfiguration attributes from. Each name references a pool by name fromeither the pools section or an external pool.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.children.<name>.priority
options.desc: Optional fixed priority for IPsec policies. This could be useful toinstall high-priority drop policies. The default of 0 uses dynamicallycalculated priorities based on the size of the traffic selectors.StrongSwan default: 0

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.remote_port
options.desc: Remote UDP port for IKE communication. If the default of port500 is used, automatic IKE port floating to port4500 is used to work around NAT issues.StrongSwan default: 500

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.children.<name>.reqid
options.desc: Fixed reqid to use for this CHILD_SA. This might be helpful in somescenarios, but works only if each CHILD_SA configuration is instantiatednot more than once. The default of 0 uses dynamic reqids, allocatedincrementally.StrongSwan default: 0

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.strongswan.extraConfig
options.desc: Contents of the strongswan.conf file.

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.remote.<name>.groups
options.desc: Authorization group memberships to require. The peer must provemembership to at least one of the specified groups. Group membership canbe certified by different means, for example by appropriate AttributeCertificates or by an AAA backend involved in the authentication.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.children.<name>.replay_window
options.desc: IPsec replay window to configure for this CHILD_SA. Larger valuesthan the default of 32 are supported using the Netlinkbackend only, a value of 0 disables IPsec replayprotection.StrongSwan default: 32

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.children.<name>.inactivity
options.desc: Timeout before closing CHILD_SA after inactivity. If no traffic hasbeen processed in either direction for the configured timeout, theCHILD_SA gets closed due to inactivity. The default value of 0 disablesinactivity checks.StrongSwan default: "0s"

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.dpd_timeout
options.desc: Charon by default uses the normal retransmission mechanism andtimeouts to check the liveness of a peer, as all messages are used forliveness checking. For compatibility reasons, with IKEv1 a custominterval may be specified; this option has no effect on connectionsusing IKEv2.StrongSwan default: "0s"

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.dpd_delay
options.desc: Interval to check the liveness of a peer actively using IKEv2INFORMATIONAL exchanges or IKEv1 R_U_THERE messages. Active DPD checkingis only enforced if no IKE or ESP/AH packet has been received for theconfigured DPD delay.StrongSwan default: "0s"

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.vips
options.desc: List of virtual IPs to request in IKEv2 configuration payloads orIKEv1 Mode Config. The wildcard addresses 0.0.0.0 and:: request an arbitrary address, specific addresses may bedefined. The responder may return a different address, though, or noneat all.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.aggressive
options.desc: Enables Aggressive Mode instead of Main Mode with IdentityProtection. Aggressive Mode is considered less secure, because the IDand HASH payloads are exchanged unprotected. This allows a passiveattacker to snoop peer identities, and even worse, start dictionaryattacks on the Preshared Key.StrongSwan default: false

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.version
options.desc: IKE major version to use for connection.1 uses IKEv1 aka ISAKMP,2 uses IKEv2.A connection using the default of 0 accepts both IKEv1 and IKEv2 asresponder, and initiates the connection actively with IKEv2.StrongSwan default: 0

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.local.<name>.certs
options.desc: List of certificate candidates to use for authentication. Thecertificates may use a relative path from the swanctl x509directory or an absolute path.The certificate used for authentication is selected based on thereceived certificate request payloads. If no appropriate CA can belocated, the first certificate is used.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.children.<name>.sha256_96
options.desc: HMAC-SHA-256 is used with 128-bit truncation with IPsec. Forcompatibility with implementations that incorrectly use 96-bittruncation this option may be enabled to configure the shortertruncation length in the kernel. This is not negotiated, so this onlyworks with peers that use the incorrect truncation length (or have thisoption enabled).StrongSwan default: false

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.children.<name>.dpd_action
options.desc: Action to perform for this CHILD_SA on DPD timeout. The default clearcloses the CHILD_SA and does not take further action. trap installs atrap policy, which will catch matching traffic and tries to re-negotiatethe tunnel on-demand. restart immediately tries to re-negotiate theCHILD_SA under a fresh IKE_SA.StrongSwan default: "clear"

options.name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections.<name>.local.<name>.pubkeys
options.desc: List of raw public key candidates to use for authentication. Thepublic keys may use a relative path from the swanctl pubkeydirectory or an absolute path.Even though multiple local public keys could be defined in principle,only the first public key in the list is used for authentication.StrongSwan default: []

See https://caddyserver.com/docs/command-line#caddy-runfor details.Any value other than null or caddyfile isonly valid when providing your own configFile.
options.value: if ((cfg.configFile != configFile) || (builtins.baseNameOf cfg.configFile) == Caddyfile) then caddyfile else null

options.name: services.caddy.configFile
options.desc: Override the configuration file used by Caddy. By default, NixOSgenerates one automatically.The configuration file is exposed at /etc/caddy/caddy_config.

options.desc: Structured configuration for Caddy to generate a Caddy JSONconfiguration file. See https://caddyserver.com/docs/json/for available options.Using a Caddyfile instead of aJSON config is highly recommended by upstream. There are only very fewexception to this.Please use a Caddyfile via services.caddy.configFile, services.caddy.virtualHosts or services.caddy.extraConfigwith services.caddy.globalConfig instead.Takes presence over most services.caddy.* options, suchas services.caddy.configFile and services.caddy.virtualHosts, if specified.

options.name: services.caddy.enableReload
options.desc: Reload Caddy instead of restarting it when configuration filechanges.Note that enabling this option requires the adminAPI to not be turned off.If you enable this option, consider setting grace_periodto a non-infinite value in services.caddy.globalConfig to prevent Caddywaiting for active connections to finish, which could delay the reloadessentially indefinitely.

options.desc: A host of an existing Let’s Encrypt certificate to use. This ismostly useful if you use DNS challenges but Caddy does not currentlysupport your provider.Note that this option does not create any certificates, nor doesit add subdomains to existing ones – you will need to create themmanually using security.acme.certs.

It is strongly recommended to setthis tohttps://acme-staging-v02.api.letsencrypt.org/directory forLet’s Encrypt’s stagingendpoint while testing or in development.Value null should be prefered for production setups, asit omits the acme_ca option to enable automaticissuer fallback.
