options.name: services.wordpress.webserver
options.desc: Whether to use apache2 or nginx for virtual host management.Further nginx configuration can be done by adaptingservices.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>. See services.nginx.virtualHostsfor further information.Further apache2 configuration can be done by adaptingservices.httpd.virtualHosts.<name>. See services.httpd.virtualHostsfor further information.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.useACMEHost
options.desc: A host of an existing Let’s Encrypt certificate to use. This isuseful if you have many subdomains and want to avoid hitting the rate limit.Alternately, you can generate a certificate through enableACME. Note thatthis option does not create any certificates, nor it does add subdomainsto existing ones – you will need to create them manually using security.acme.certs.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.sslServerKey
options.desc: Path to server SSL certificate key.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.sslServerChain
options.desc: Path to server SSL chain file.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.sslServerCert
options.desc: Path to server SSL certificate.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.serverAliases
options.desc: Additional names of virtual hosts served by this virtual hostconfiguration.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.servedFiles
options.desc: This option provides a simple way to serve individual, staticfiles.This option has been deprecated and will be removed in a futureversion of NixOS. You can achieve the same result by making use of thelocations.<name>.alias option.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.servedDirs
options.desc: This option provides a simple way to serve static directories.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.robotsEntries
options.desc: Specification of pages to be ignored by web crawlers. See http://www.robotstxt.org/ fordetails.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.onlySSL
options.desc: Whether to enable HTTPS and reject plain HTTP connections. This willset defaults for listen to listen on all interfaces on port443.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.logFormat
options.desc: Log format for Apache’s log files. Possible values are: combined,common, referer, agent.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.locations.<name>.proxyPass
options.desc: Sets up a simple reverse proxy as described by https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/howto/reverse_proxy.html#simple.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.locations.<name>.priority
options.desc: Order of this location block in relation to the others in the vhost.The semantics are the same as with lib.mkOrder. Smallervalues have a greater priority.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.locations.<name>.index
options.desc: Adds DirectoryIndex directive. See https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/mod_dir.html#directoryindex.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.locations.<name>.extraConfig
options.desc: These lines go to the end of the location verbatim.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.locations.<name>.alias
options.desc: Alias directory for requests. See https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/mod_alias.html#alias.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.locations
options.desc: Declarative location config. See https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/core.html#locationfor details.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.listenAddresses
options.desc: Listen addresses for this virtual host. Compared tolisten this only sets the addresses and the ports arechosen automatically.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.listen.*.ssl
options.desc: Whether to enable SSL (https) support.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.listen.*.port
options.desc: Port to listen on
options.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.listen.*.ip
options.desc: IP to listen on. 0.0.0.0 for IPv4 only, * for all.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.listen
options.desc: Listen addresses and ports for this virtual host.This option overrides addSSL, forceSSL andonlySSL.If you only want to set the addresses manually and not the ports,take a look at listenAddresses.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.http2
options.desc: Whether to enable HTTP 2. HTTP/2 is supported in all multi-processingmodules that come with httpd. However, if you use the prefork mpm,there will be severe restrictions. Refer to https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/howto/http2.html#mpm-configfor details.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.hostName
options.desc: Canonical hostname for the server.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.globalRedirect
options.desc: If set, all requests for this host are redirected permanently to thegiven URL.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.forceSSL
options.desc: Whether to add a separate nginx server block that permanentlyredirects (301) all plain HTTP traffic to HTTPS. This will set defaultsfor listen to listen on all interfaces on the respectivedefault ports (80, 443), where the non-SSL listens are used for theredirect vhosts.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.extraConfig
options.desc: These lines go to httpd.conf verbatim. They will go after directoriesand directory aliases defined by default.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.enableUserDir
options.desc: Whether to enable serving ~/public_html as /~«username».

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.enableACME
options.desc: Whether to ask Let’s Encrypt to sign a certificate for this vhost.Alternately, you can use an existing certificate through useACMEHost.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.documentRoot
options.desc: The path of Apache’s document root directory. If left undefined, anempty directory in the Nix store will be used as root.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.adminAddr
options.desc: E-mail address of the server administrator.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.addSSL
options.desc: Whether to enable HTTPS in addition to plain HTTP. This will setdefaults for listen to listen on all interfaces on therespective default ports (80, 443).

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost.acmeRoot
options.desc: Directory for the acme challenge which is PUBLIC, don’t put certs orkeys in here. Set to null to inherit from config.security.acme.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.virtualHost
options.desc: Apache configuration can be done by adapting services.httpd.virtualHosts.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.uploadsDir
options.desc: This directory is used for uploads of pictures. The directory passedhere is automatically created and permissions adjusted as required.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.themes
options.desc: Path(s) to respective theme(s) which are copied from the ‘theme’directory.These themes need to be packaged before use, see example.
options.type: (attribute set of path) or (list of path) convertible to it

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.plugins
options.desc: Path(s) to respective plugin(s) which are copied from the ‘plugins’directory.These plugins need to be packaged before use, see example.
options.type: (attribute set of path) or (list of path) convertible to it

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.mergedConfig
options.desc: Read only representation of the final configuration.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.languages
options.desc: List of path(s) to respective language(s) which are copied from the‘languages’ directory.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.fontsDir
options.desc: This directory is used to download fonts from a remote location, e.g.to host google fonts locally.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.extraConfig
options.desc: Any additional text to be appended to the wp-config.php configurationfile. This is a PHP script. For configuration settings, see https://codex.wordpress.org/Editing_wp-config.php.Note: Please pass structured settings viaservices.wordpress.sites.‹name›.settings instead.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.database.user
options.desc: Database user.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.database.socket
options.desc: Path to the unix socket file to use for authentication.

options.name: services.wordpress.sites.<name>.database.port
options.desc: Database host port.
options.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

name: Grafana
desc: Gorgeous metric viz, dashboards & editors for Graphite, InfluxDB & OpenTSDB

options.name: services.grafana.settings
options.desc: Grafana settings. See https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/setup-grafana/configure-grafana/for available options. INI format is used.
options.type: attribute set of section of an INI file (attrs of INI atom (null, bool, int, float or string) or a non-empty list of them)

options.name: services.grafana-image-renderer.settings
options.desc: Configuration attributes for grafana-image-renderer.See https://github.com/grafana/grafana-image-renderer/blob/ce1f81438e5f69c7fd7c73ce08bab624c4c92e25/default.jsonfor supported values.

options.name: services.grafana-image-renderer.provisionGrafana
options.desc: Whether to enable Grafana configuration forgrafana-image-renderer.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.smtp.password
options.desc: Password used for authentication. Please note that the contents ofthis option will end up in a world-readable Nix store. Use the fileprovider pointing at a reasonably secured file in the local filesystemto work around that. Look at the documentation for details: https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/setup-grafana/configure-grafana/#file-provider

options.name: services.grafana.settings.security.secret_key
options.desc: Secret key used for signing. Please note that the contents of thisoption will end up in a world-readable Nix store. Use the file providerpointing at a reasonably secured file in the local filesystem to workaround that. Look at the documentation for details: https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/setup-grafana/configure-grafana/#file-provider

options.name: services.grafana.settings.security.admin_password
options.desc: Default admin password. Please note that the contents of this optionwill end up in a world-readable Nix store. Use the file providerpointing at a reasonably secured file in the local filesystem to workaround that. Look at the documentation for details: https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/setup-grafana/configure-grafana/#file-provider

options.name: services.grafana.provision.notifiers.*.secure_settings
options.desc: Secure settings for the notifier type. Please note that the contentsof this option will end up in a world-readable Nix store. Use the fileprovider pointing at a reasonably secured file in the local filesystemto work around that. Look at the documentation for details: https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/setup-grafana/configure-grafana/#file-provider

options.name: services.grafana.provision.datasources.settings.datasources.*.secureJsonData
options.desc: Datasource specific secure configuration. Please note that thecontents of this option will end up in a world-readable Nix store. Usethe file provider pointing at a reasonably secured file in the localfilesystem to work around that. Look at the documentation for details:https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/setup-grafana/configure-grafana/#file-provider

options.name: services.grafana.settings.database.password
options.desc: The database user’s password (not applicable forsqlite3).Please note that the contents of this option will end up in aworld-readable Nix store. Use the file provider pointing at a reasonablysecured file in the local filesystem to work around that. Look at thedocumentation for details: https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/setup-grafana/configure-grafana/#file-provider

options.name: services.parsedmarc.provision.grafana.dashboard
options.desc: Whether the official parsedmarc grafana dashboard should beprovisioned to the local grafana instance.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.server.serve_from_sub_path
options.desc: Serve Grafana from subpath specified in the root_urlsetting. By default it is set to false for compatibilityreasons.By enabling this setting and using a subpath in root_urlabove, e.g. root_url = "http://localhost:3000/grafana",Grafana is accessible on http://localhost:3000/grafana. Ifaccessed without subpath, Grafana will redirect to an URL with thesubpath.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.users.hidden_users
options.desc: This is a comma-separated list of usernames. Users specified here arehidden in the Grafana UI. They are still visible to Grafanaadministrators and to themselves.

options.name: services.grafana_reporter.grafana.protocol
options.desc: Grafana protocol.

options.name: services.grafana_reporter.grafana.port
options.desc: Grafana port.
options.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

options.name: services.grafana_reporter.grafana.addr
options.desc: Grafana address.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.server.cdn_url
options.desc: Specify a full HTTP URL address to the root of your Grafana CDNassets. Grafana will add edition and version paths.For example, given a cdn url likehttps://cdn.myserver.com grafana will try to load ajavascript file fromhttp://cdn.myserver.com/grafana-oss/7.4.0/public/build/app.<hash>.js.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.server.router_logging
options.desc: Set to true for Grafana to log all HTTP requests (notjust errors). These are logged as Info level events to the Grafanalog.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.database.name
options.desc: The name of the Grafana database.

options.name: services.grafana.provision.notifiers
options.desc: Grafana notifier configuration.

options.name: services.grafana.package
options.desc: The grafana package to use.

options.name: services.grafana.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable grafana.

options.name: services.grafana.provision.datasources
options.desc: Declaratively provision Grafana’s datasources.

options.name: services.grafana.provision.dashboards
options.desc: Declaratively provision Grafana’s dashboards.

options.name: services.grafana-agent.package
options.desc: The grafana-agent package to use.

options.name: services.grafana-agent.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable grafana-agent.

options.name: services.grafana.provision.dashboards.settings
options.desc: Grafana dashboard configuration in Nix. Can’t be used with services.grafana.provision.dashboards.pathsimultaneously. See https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/administration/provisioning/#dashboardsfor supported options.

options.name: services.grafana.provision.alerting.templates.settings
options.desc: Grafana templates configuration in Nix. Can’t be used with services.grafana.provision.alerting.templates.pathsimultaneously. See https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/administration/provisioning/#templatesfor supported options.

options.name: services.grafana.provision.alerting.rules.settings
options.desc: Grafana rules configuration in Nix. Can’t be used with services.grafana.provision.alerting.rules.pathsimultaneously. See https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/administration/provisioning/#rulesfor supported options.

options.name: services.grafana-image-renderer.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable grafana-image-renderer.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.analytics.check_for_updates
options.desc: When set to false, disables checking for new versions ofGrafana from Grafana’s GitHub repository. When enabled, the check for anew version runs every 10 minutes. It will notify, via the UI, when anew version is available. The check itself will not prompt anyauto-updates of the Grafana software, nor will it send any sensitiveinformation.

options.name: services.grafana.provision.datasources.settings
options.desc: Grafana datasource configuration in Nix. Can’t be used with services.grafana.provision.datasources.pathsimultaneously. See https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/administration/provisioning/#data-sourcesfor supported options.

options.name: services.grafana.provision.alerting.policies.settings
options.desc: Grafana notification policies configuration in Nix. Can’t be usedwith services.grafana.provision.alerting.policies.pathsimultaneously. See https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/administration/provisioning/#notification-policiesfor supported options.

options.name: services.grafana.provision.alerting.muteTimings.settings
options.desc: Grafana mute timings configuration in Nix. Can’t be used with services.grafana.provision.alerting.muteTimings.pathsimultaneously. See https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/administration/provisioning/#mute-timingsfor supported options.

options.name: services.grafana.provision.alerting.contactPoints.settings
options.desc: Grafana contact points configuration in Nix. Can’t be used with services.grafana.provision.alerting.contactPoints.pathsimultaneously. See https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/administration/provisioning/#contact-pointsfor supported options.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.security.admin_email
options.desc: The email of the default Grafana Admin, created on startup.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.security.disable_initial_admin_creation
options.desc: Disable creation of admin user on first start of Grafana.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.paths.plugins
options.desc: Directory where grafana will automatically scan and look forplugins

options.name: services.tempo.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable Grafana Tempo.

options.name: services.loki.package
options.desc: The grafana-loki package to use.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.security.cookie_secure
options.desc: Set to true if you host Grafana behind HTTPS.

options.name: services.grafana.provision.dashboards.settings.providers.*.options.path
options.desc: Path grafana will watch for dashboards. Required when using the‘file’ type.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.server.socket_gid
options.desc: GID where the socket should be set when protocol=socket.Make sure that the target group is in the group of Grafana process andthat Grafana process is the file owner before you change this setting.It is recommended to set the gid as http server user gid. Not set whenthe value is -1.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.server.root_url
options.desc: This is the full URL used to access Grafana from a web browser. Thisis important if you use Google or GitHub OAuth authentication (for thecallback URL to be correct).This setting is also important if you have a reverse proxy in frontof Grafana that exposes it through a subpath. In that case add thesubpath to the end of this URL setting.

options.name: services.grafana.declarativePlugins
options.desc: If non-null, then a list of packages containing Grafana plugins toinstall. If set, plugins cannot be manually installed.

options.name: services.grafana-image-renderer.settings.service.logging.level
options.desc: The log-level of the grafana-image-renderer.service-unit.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.database.isolation_level
options.desc: Only the MySQL driver supports isolation levels in Grafana. In casethe value is empty, the driver’s default isolation level is applied.
options.type: null or one of READ-UNCOMMITTED, READ-COMMITTED, REPEATABLE-READ, SERIALIZABLE

options.name: services.grafana.settings.server.socket_mode
options.desc: Mode where the socket should be set whenprotocol=socket. Make sure that Grafana process is the fileowner before you change this setting.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.server.socket
options.desc: Path where the socket should be created whenprotocol=socket. Make sure that Grafana has appropriatepermissions before you change this setting.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.security.allow_embedding
options.desc: When false, the HTTP headerX-Frame-Options: deny will be set in Grafana HTTP responseswhich will instruct browsers to not allow rendering Grafana in a<frame>, <iframe>,<embed> or <object>. The main goalis to mitigate the risk of Clickjacking.

options.name: services.grafana.settings.paths.provisioning
options.desc: Folder that contains provisioning config files that grafana willapply on startup and while running. Don’t change the value of thisoption if you are planning to useservices.grafana.provision options.
options.value: directory with links to files generated from services.grafana.provision
